comments.body: I am not sure about this.... Windows is not my forte but I have the impression that `conda-build` should take care of that for you, no?

Nope, not in my case at least. If you install [Microsoft Visual C++ Compiler for Python 2.7](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=44266), it nowadays installs somewhere in the user's appdata folder, while conda build (only) tries to invoke vcvarsall.bat where it used to be located in the full Visual Studio 2008 installation (somewhere in Program Files). The build did not succeed on my machine without these lines at least, because vcvarsall could not be found, but this story might be different for the conda forge VMs which have the official full VS2008 tools installed (and not the version for Python). With VS versions other than VS2008 this was not a problem.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +9,13 @@		set PATH=!VC9DIR!;"%PATH%"
		if %ARCH% == 32 call vcvarsall.bat x86
		if %ARCH% == 64 call vcvarsall.bat amd64
		:: vcvarsall does something strange with PATH, preventing xcopy to be found later. Fix this
		set PATH=!PATH!;%SYSTEMROOT%\system32
